author: Richard Hossli

review: We got this after becoming fed up with the crap-tastic apps and interface on our internet-connected Blu Ray player. It's pretty much perfect. Setup was an absolute breeze; I spent more time untangling cords and unplugging things to make room for the power adapter than I did actually configuring it. Awesome app/channel selection. Having a remote that doesn't require line-of-site is a bigger benefit than you might initially imagine; no more trying to shoo the cats away from an IR receiver!As this was of particular interest to me, let me talk about streaming your personal media collection with this gadget. Yes, you can, fairly easily. It requires a third-party application called Plex, which I think ends up costing $5 after a 30-day trial. It's fairly easy to configure, with the trickiest part being mastering the file naming conventions it uses. Once you've got that set up, the Roku provides a very slick method of organizing and watching your media collection on your TV.About my only complaint is that the quicklink buttons on the remote aren't reprogrammable. I mean, Blockbuster? Really? Is it still the 90s somewhere? I'd much rather have a Hulu button.
